page.title: 17 INSECTS
page.content: Chemical sprays kill some insects, but many others survive. The most common insect is the midge, seen in vast numbers after 9p.m. Amongst the rarest insects are a hoverfly discovered at Wandlebury in 1982 and hornet. 32 bee and wasp species have been seen at Wandlebury, including the bumble and wall mason bees, tree and ruby tail wasps and hornets. Many lesser stag beetles are found. Scolytus scolytus, carrier of Dutch elm disease is declining in numbers now that many elms have been lost. Some people visit the area specifically to spot insects, especially when ivy flowers. Moth-trap studies are being carried out. Species have not yet been officially listed, but include the fairly rare lobster moth and the common holly blue butterfly.
